questions.question:
Question 1: A 23-year-old man came to the OPD with complaints of vomiting for which he was prescribed 
metoclopramide. What is the primary mechanism of action of this drug?

options.b: Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscles

questions.explanation:
The mechanism of action of metoclopramide is primarily D2 antagonism in the chemoreceptor 
trigger zone. Metoclopramide has the following actions: 828 
Sold by @itachibot • 5HT4 receptor agonism - prokinetic action • 5HT3 receptor antagonism - anti-emetic action at higher doses • Peripheral D2 antagonism - prokinetic action • Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscles

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following actions is exhibited by metoclopramide?

options.a: Inhibits cholinergic smooth muscle stimulation in the gastrointestinal tract
options.b: Decreases the lower esophageal sphincter pressure

questions.explanation:
Metoclopramide enhances gastrointestinal motility. Acetylcholine increases gastrointestinal motility and lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone. 
Dopamine which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter suppresses ACh release. This decreases 
gastrointestinal motility and LES tone. Therefore, D2 receptor inhibition augments ACh release 
and enhances GI motility and LES tone. The action of metoclopramide is generally confined to the upper digestive tract and an increase in 
colonic motility is clinically insignificant.

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient presented to the casualty with signs of dehydration due to severe vomiting. The 
intern gave the patient a parenteral medication, following which the patient developed 
grimacing and abnormal posturing. What could have been the inciting drug for this reaction?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario describes the adverse effects characteristic of metoclopramide. The 
most common adverse effects of metoclopramide involve the central nervous system because it 
crosses the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and blocks the central D2 receptors. The adverse effects include: • Restlessness • Drowsiness • Insomnia • Anxiety • Agitation • Extrapyramidal effects - acute reaction with high doses and long-term therapy. (due to central 
dopamine receptor blockade) • Dystonias • Akathisia • Parkinsonian features • Tardive dyskinesia Adverse events are more common among the elderly. Long-term use should be avoided unless 
absolutely necessary. 829 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: 820 
Sold by @itachibot A patient developed abnormal posturing and grimacing following the administration of 
metoclopramide. Which drug will you administer to manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of dystonia associated with D2 blocker (metoclopramide) use. 
Promethazine is the drug of choice. It is a first-generation antihistaminic having significant central anticholinergic activity.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following drugs is implicated in prolonging QT interval and causing serious 
arrhythmias?
questions.explanation:
Cisapride is associated with prolongation of QT interval and causation of serious ventricular 
arrhythmias. Prolongation of QT interval is due to blockade of rapid delayed rectifier potassium channels. It is 
banned or has restricted use in most of the countries. Ondansetron is associated with asymptomatic electrocardiogram changes, including prolongation 
of PT and QTc intervals.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following drugs do not act as a prokinetic agent by 5HT4 agonism?
questions.explanation:
Domperidone does not have any 5HT4 agonist action. It mainly acts by D2 antagonist action. 5HT4 agonism and D2 antagonism can result in prokinetic action by increasing the cholinergic 
activity of the gut. The 5HT4 agonist action is shown by: • Metoclopramide • Cisapride • Mosapride • Itopride • Renzapride

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is not a prokinetic?
questions.explanation:
Diphenylmethane is not a prokinetic agent. Its derivative (Bisacodyl) is used as a laxative. Prokinetic agents are the drugs that increase GI motility and transit of material in the GI tract. 
These agents include: • Dopamine receptor antagonists- metoclopramide and domperidone • Serotonin receptor agonists- cisapride and prucalopride • Motilin • Macrolide antibiotics mimicking motilin - erythromycin 830 
Sold by @itachibot • Miscellaneous agents: • Sincalide (C-terminal octapeptide of CCK) • Camicinal (motilin receptor agonist) • Relamorelin (ghrelin receptor agonist) • Velusetrag and naronapride (5HT4 agonists)

questions.question:
Question 8: 821 
Sold by @itachibot A 45-year-old male with unhealthy eating practices now complains of constipation. He took 
bisacodyl, following which he had symptomatic relief. Which group of drugs does this belong 
to?
questions.explanation:
Bisacodyl is a stimulant laxative. Stimulant laxatives act by irritation of the intestinal mucosa and direct action on myenteric plexus 
neurons stimulating motility and secretion. Examples of stimulant/irritant laxatives are: • Bisacodyl • Sodium picosulfate • Anthraquinones like senna, cascara sagrada • Castor oil

questions.question:
Question 9: A colonoscopy of an elderly patient revealed brownish pigmented lesions as shown below. He 
admitted to chronic laxative abuse. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to cause 
this condition?
questions.explanation:
The above colonoscopy image depicts a brownish moiré pattern that is indicative of melanosis 
coli. Chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna and cascara sagrada can cause melanosis 
coli. Bisacodyl is also implicated in causing melanosis coli.

questions.question:
Question 10: You want to prescribe a bulk-forming laxative to an elderly patient with constipation. Which 
among the following would you not prescribe? 822 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Liquid paraffin is not a bulk-forming laxative. It is a mineral oil and acts as a stool softener. It is rarely used in clinical practice today because of its drawbacks, such as: • Bland and unpleasant taste • Risk of lipoid pneumonia • Anal leakage Bulk-forming laxatives are: • Bran • Psyllium • Methylcellulose 831 
Sold by @itachibot • Polycarbophil

questions.question:
Question 11: A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatric OPD by his mother with complaints of acute 
watery diarrhea for 2 days. Oral rehydration solution, zinc supplement, and a peripheral 
enkephalinase inhibitor were prescribed. Which of the following drugs did he prescribe?
questions.explanation:
Racecadotril is a peripheral enkephalinase inhibitor. Enkephalins are endogenous delta-opioid receptor agonists that decrease intestinal secretions 
without affecting motility. Enkephalinase is the enzyme that degrades enkephalin. Racecadotril, by inhibiting the enkephalinase enzyme increases enkephalin level and acts as an 
antisecretory agent in diarrhea. It has minimal/no effect on motility. Racecadotril is indicated for 
symptomatic treatment of diarrhea in infants and children. Options B and C: Diphenoxylate and loperamide are -opioid receptor agonists. Option D: Linaclotide is a guanylate cyclase agonist.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 30-year-old male who is on anti-retroviral therapy presents with complaints of diarrhea for 
three days. An infectious etiology is ruled out on work-up. Which of the following drugs is 
preferred to manage his diarrhea?
questions.explanation:
This is a case of non-infectious diarrhea associated with antiretroviral therapy (ART). Crofelemer 
is indicated for non-infectious diarrhea associated with ART in HIV/AIDS. Crofelemer has minimal systemic absorption. It acts by inhibiting the cyclic AMP-stimulated 
CFTR chloride channel and calcium-activated chloride channels on the luminal side of the 
intestine.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 38-year-old woman complains of recurrent episodes of constipation and crampy abdominal 
pain for the last 4 months. The pain is relieved on defecation. After investigations, a diagnosis 
of irritable bowel syndrome with constipation is considered. Which of the following drugs 
would you prescribe?
questions.explanation:
The drug used in irritable bowel syndrome with constipation is lubiprostone. It is approved for chronic idiopathic constipation and constipation-predominant irritable bowel 
syndrome (in female patients >18 years). It acts by stimulating Cl-channels in the intestine and 
increasing fluid secretion in the gut. This decreases the transit time. Eluxadoline is an FDA-approved opioid drug for the treatment of diarrhea-predominant IBS in 
adults.

questions.question: Question 14: The use of which of the following drugs is associated with ischemic colitis?
questions.explanation:
Ischemic colitis is associated with the use of alosetron. It is a 5HT3 antagonist that may suppress 
intestinal relaxation leading to ischemic colitis in susceptible individuals. It is approved for resistant diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome in female patients. It is either withdrawn/ has restricted use because of the serious side effect. 832 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient who is suffering from chronic constipation is prescribed a guanylcycline C agonist. 
Identify the drug.
questions.explanation:
The guanylcycline-C (GC-C) agonist indicated in chronic constipation is linaclotide. Linaclotide is a peptide agonist that activates GC-C which leads to increased synthesis of 
cyclic-GMP. This results in enhanced chloride and bicarbonate secretion into the intestinal lumen 
leading to increased water secretion and enhanced motility. It is indicated in constipation-predominant IBS in females and in chronic idiopathic constipation 
in adults.

questions.question:
Question 16: Prucalopride is a  
.
questions.explanation:
Prucalopride is a specific 5HT4 receptor agonist which increases bowel movements. It is approved for use in women with chronic constipation where other laxatives have failed to 
provide relief.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 40-year-old woman suffering from erratic bowel habits for the past few months is 
diagnosed with diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome. Which antibiotic is 
specifically approved for the treatment of her condition?
questions.explanation:
The antibiotic that is specifically approved for diarrhea-predominant IBS is rifaximin. It is an 
RNA synthesis inhibitor. It may provide benefit by altering the gastrointestinal flora favorably. Rifabutin, rifampicin and rifapentine are antitubercular agents.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 20-year-old primiparous woman came to the OPD with complaints of nausea and vomiting 
at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is specifically indicated to provide 
symptomatic relief in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Doxylamine is indicated with pyridoxine to reduce mild to moderate nausea and vomiting in the 
early stages of pregnancy. It is a histamine H1 antagonist and its efficacy is improved when combined with pyridoxine. Combinations of domperidone, dolasetron and metoclopramide with pyridoxine are not 
specifically indicated in pregnancy.

questions.question:
Question 19: What is the drug of choice in a patient complaining of nausea and vomiting, 2 days after 
commencement of a cisplatin-based chemotherapeutic regimen?
questions.explanation:
This patient is most likely suffering from delayed emesis associated with cancer chemotherapy. Combined therapy with aprepitant (NK-1/ neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist), a 5-HT3-receptor 
antagonist, and dexamethasone is the best treatment in delayed emesis associated with cancer 
chemotherapy. 833 
Sold by @itachibot Delayed chemotherapy-induced vomiting is any emesis occurring >24 hours after 
chemotherapy. If NK-1 receptor antagonists are not used in the combination, delayed emesis is 
prevented only in 30% of the patients. Usage of 5HT3 antagonists alone has no role in the 
treatment of delayed emesis.

questions.question:
Question 20: An AIDS patient presents with anorexia and weight loss. Which of the following is a naturally 
extracted cannabinoid that is approved for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Dronabinol or delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol is a cannabinoid that can be extracted naturally. It is the only cannabinoid that is approved for anorexia and weight loss associated with AIDS. It is 
obtained from the marijuana plant or can be synthesized chemically. Option B: Nabilone is a synthetic cannabinoid. Dronabinol and nabilone are approved for the treatment of refractory cases of 
chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Option C: Tibolone is a 19-norsteroid derivative specifically to be used for hormone replacement 
therapy. Option D: Cannabidiol is a cannabinoid approved for the treatment of seizures associated 
with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, Dravet syndrome, or tuberous sclerosis complex.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following statements about aprepitant is false?

options.c: Ameliorate nausea and vomiting induced by chemotherapy

questions.explanation:
Aprepitant is a high-affinity NK1 receptor antagonist that blocks the emetic action of substance P. Aprepitant is well absorbed orally and crosses the blood-brain barrier. Co-administration of oral aprepitant with dexamethasone and ondansetron significantly enhances 
the antiemetic efficacy against the highly emetogenic side effects of chemotherapeutic drugs like 
cisplatin and cyclophosphamide. It is metabolized in the liver by the CYP450 enzyme.

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following antiemetic drugs also decreases acid secretion due to its action on H1 
receptors?
questions.explanation:
An antiemetic drug that also decreases acid secretion due to its action on H1 histamine receptors 
is promethazine. The central anticholinergic activity of promethazine is responsible for antiemetic action.

questions.question: Question 23: The 5HT3 antagonist having maximum potency in chemotherapy-induced vomiting is:
questions.explanation:
The 5HT3 antagonist having maximum potency in chemotherapy-induced vomiting is 
palonosetron. 834 
Sold by @itachibot It has a high affinity for 5HT3 and is also the longest-acting 5HT3 antagonist. This makes it more 
effective in delayed emesis associated with chemotherapy. During chemotherapy, there is cell lysis and 5HT (serotonin) is released from the gut mucosa. The 
released serotonin acts on the 5HT3 receptors, activating the vagal afferents in the gut that carry 
the emetogenic impulses to the nucleus tractus solitarius and chemoreceptor trigger zone. The 
selective blockade of 5HT3 receptors reduces the emetogenic impulses. Granisetron, dolasetron, and ondansetron are also effective for chemotherapy-induced vomiting. Cilansetron is a new 5HT3 antagonist indicated for irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea.

questions.question:
Question 24: Most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting is 
.
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, the most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting is 
granisetron. Granisetron is a 5HT3 receptor antagonist. They are the most effective drugs for the treatment of 
chemotherapy-induced and post-operative nausea and vomiting. Palonosetron is a second-generation 5HT3 antagonist that has the highest affinity for 5HT3 
receptors and has the maximum potency. It is also the longest acting that makes it effective in 
delayed emesis associated with chemotherapy. Palonosetron has minimal/no propensity to cause 
QT interval prolongation.

questions.question: Question 25: QT interval prolongation is minimal with which of the following 5-HT3 antagonists?
questions.explanation:
Palonosetron is a second-generation 5-HT3 antagonist and has minimal/no propensity to cause 
QT prolongation. First-generation 5-HT3 antagonists have an increased risk of QT interval prolongation. Intravenous dolasetron is contraindicated for prophylaxis of chemotherapy-induced nausea and 
vomiting for the same reason.

questions.question: Question 26: Which of the following NK1 receptor antagonists has the longest half-life?
questions.explanation:
Rolapitant has the longest plasma half-life of 180 hours. It is a highly selective NK1 receptor 
antagonist.

questions.question:
Question 27: A young male developed 5 episodes of loose stools 2 hours after eating in a restaurant. He is 
afebrile and has mild dehydration. What should be the treatment?
questions.explanation:
It is a case of acute diarrhea in an afebrile, stable patient which can be managed with ORS alone. Management of diarrhea: 835 
Sold by @itachibot • Mild-moderate dehydration - ORS. • Severe dehydration- IV fluids are given. • Afebrile patient - No antibiotics are given. • Febrile patient - empirical antibiotics. If only bacterial etiology is suspected, ciprofloxacin is 
given. If giardiasis is suspected, metronidazole or tinidazole are recommended.

questions.question:
Question 28: You and your friend plan for a mountain trip for the day after. What medication would you 
advise him to help with his motion sickness?
questions.explanation:
In the above case, a scopolamine patch the night before the trip should be advised. Treatment for motion sickness : • Scopolamine patch- preferred, most effective. • Do not give to children <10 years of age. • Place patch behind the ears at least 4 hours before travel and replace every 72 hours as needed. • Transdermal patch – Most effective • Oral dose - 0.4–0.6 mg one hour before travel and then TID may be recommended. • Cinnarizine – 30mg, 2 hours prior to travel, and 15mg TID as required. Not as effective as 
scopolamine. Moderately effective. • Promethazine • Other drugs (minimally effective): • Cyclizine • Dimenhydrinate • Diphenhydramine • Meclizine PPI’s / ranitidine / traditional ginger – all are ineffective. 836 
Sold by @itachibot Cell Cycle Specific Cytotoxic Drugs
